articles.title: Plastic can be programmed to have a lifespan of days, months or years
articles.summary: Inspired by natural polymers like DNA, chemists have devised a way to engineer plastic so it breaks down when it is no longer needed, rather than polluting the environment
articles.content:
Inspired by natural polymers like DNA, chemists have devised a way to engineer plastic so it breaks down when it is no longer needed, rather than polluting the environment

We throw away hundreds of millions of tonnes of plastic each year Cavan Images/Alamy

Chemical additions to plastic that mimic natural polymers like DNA can create materials that break down in days, months or years rather than littering the environment for centuries. Researchers hope their new technique will lead to plastic products that serve their purpose and then safely self-destruct.

In 2022, more than a quarter of a billion tonnes of plastic was discarded globally, and only 14 per cent was recycled – the rest was either burned or buried. The promise of a practical, biodegradable plastic has been around for at least 35 years, and there have been efforts to make such materials using everything from bamboo to seaweed. But, in truth, many such materials are difficult to compost and their producers make unrealistic claims.

Advertisement

Now, Yuwei Gu and his colleagues at Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey, are developing a technique to create plastics with finely-tuned lifespans that could quickly break down either in compost or in the natural environment.

Gu wondered why natural, long-stranded polymers like DNA and RNA can break down relatively quickly, but synthetic ones, such as plastics, can’t, and if there was a way to replicate their process.

Natural polymers contain chemical structures called neighbouring groups that aid in deconstruction. These structures power internal reactions called nucleophilic attacks that sever the bonds in polymer chains – something that requires a great deal of energy with normal plastics.

Free newsletter Sign up to The Earth Edition Unmissable news about our planet, delivered straight to your inbox each month. Sign up to newsletter

Gu and his team created artificial chemical structures that mimic these neighbouring groups, and added them when making new plastics. They found that the resulting material could break down easily and that by altering the structure of the additions, they could fine-tune how long the material remained intact before deconstructing.

After the plastic breaks down, the long polymer chains are converted into small fragments, which Gu hopes will either be used to make new plastics or will safely dissolve into the environment.

“This strategy works best for plastics that benefit from controlled degradation over days to months, so we see strong potential for applications like food packaging and other short-lived consumer materials,” says Gu. “At the moment, it is less suited for plastics that must remain stable for decades before breaking down – such as construction materials or long-term structural components.”

But there are several problems to solve before this type of plastic can be used commercially. The liquid left over after the plastics deconstruct is made up of fragments of polymer chains, and further tests are needed to ensure that this soup of parts isn’t toxic and can therefore be safely released into nature.

Also, ultraviolet light is currently needed to initiate the deconstruction, although ambient sunlight is sufficient. So until the group finds ways to create materials that can break down in the dark, any plastic that is buried or otherwise covered up will remain in the environment almost indefinitely.
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant scientific breakthrough in creating plastics that can be programmed to biodegrade within a controlled timeframe, addressing the global plastic pollution crisis. This innovation has broad environmental implications by potentially reducing plastic waste accumulation and pollution. The article provides substantial detail about the scientific approach, potential applications, and current limitations, making it a focused and meaningful story.
articles.personality_title: Scientists create plastic that breaks down on command
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Every year, the world throws away hundreds of millions of tonnes of plastic. Most of this plastic does not break down easily and ends up polluting the environment for hundreds of years. Scientists have been looking for ways to make plastic that can disappear safely after use.

**What happened** – Researchers at Rutgers University found a way to make plastic that can break down after a certain time, from days to years. They copied natural molecules like DNA, which have special chemical parts that help them break down quickly. By adding similar parts to plastic, they made it possible for plastic to fall apart when it is no longer needed.

**Impact** – This new plastic could be very useful for things like food packaging or other products that only need to last a short time. Instead of staying in the environment forever, the plastic can break down safely. This could reduce a lot of plastic waste. However, the plastic needs sunlight to start breaking down, so it won’t work well if buried underground yet.

**What's next step** – Scientists need to test if the broken-down pieces of plastic are safe for nature. They also want to find ways for the plastic to break down without light, so it can disappear even if it is covered or buried. After these steps, the plastic might become available for everyday use.

**One-sentence takeaway** – A new kind of plastic can be designed to break down safely after use, offering a smarter way to reduce plastic pollution.
articles.personality_title_fr: Des scientifiques créent un plastique qui se décompose sur commande
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Chaque année, le monde jette des centaines de millions de tonnes de plastique. La plupart de ces plastiques ne se décomposent pas facilement et polluent l’environnement pendant des centaines d’années. Les scientifiques cherchent des moyens de fabriquer un plastique qui peut disparaître en toute sécurité après usage.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Des chercheurs de l’Université Rutgers ont trouvé un moyen de fabriquer un plastique qui peut se décomposer après un certain temps, de quelques jours à plusieurs années. Ils ont imité des molécules naturelles comme l’ADN, qui possèdent des parties chimiques spéciales aidant à leur décomposition rapide. En ajoutant des parties similaires au plastique, ils ont rendu possible sa décomposition quand il n’est plus nécessaire.

**Impact** – Ce nouveau plastique pourrait être très utile pour des objets comme les emballages alimentaires ou d’autres produits à courte durée de vie. Au lieu de rester dans l’environnement pour toujours, le plastique peut se décomposer en toute sécurité. Cela pourrait réduire beaucoup de déchets plastiques. Cependant, le plastique a besoin de lumière du soleil pour commencer à se décomposer, donc il ne fonctionne pas encore bien s’il est enterré.

**Étape suivante** – Les scientifiques doivent vérifier si les morceaux de plastique décomposé sont sûrs pour la nature. Ils veulent aussi trouver des moyens pour que le plastique se décompose sans lumière, afin qu’il puisse disparaître même s’il est recouvert ou enterré. Après ces étapes, le plastique pourrait être utilisé au quotidien.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Un nouveau type de plastique peut être conçu pour se décomposer en toute sécurité après usage, offrant une solution plus intelligente pour réduire la pollution plastique.
articles.personality_title_es: Científicos crean plástico que se descompone cuando se desea
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Cada año, el mundo tira cientos de millones de toneladas de plástico. La mayoría de estos plásticos no se descomponen fácilmente y contaminan el medio ambiente durante cientos de años. Los científicos han buscado formas de hacer plásticos que desaparezcan de manera segura después de usarse.

**Qué pasó** – Investigadores de la Universidad Rutgers encontraron una manera de crear plástico que puede descomponerse después de cierto tiempo, desde días hasta años. Imitaron moléculas naturales como el ADN, que tienen partes químicas especiales que ayudan a descomponerse rápido. Al añadir partes similares al plástico, hicieron posible que se descomponga cuando ya no se necesita.

**Impacto** – Este nuevo plástico podría ser muy útil para cosas como empaques de alimentos u otros productos de corta duración. En lugar de quedarse en el ambiente para siempre, el plástico puede descomponerse de forma segura. Esto podría reducir mucha basura plástica. Sin embargo, el plástico necesita luz solar para comenzar a descomponerse, por lo que aún no funciona bien si está enterrado.

**Próximo paso** – Los científicos deben probar si las piezas de plástico descompuesto son seguras para la naturaleza. También quieren encontrar formas para que el plástico se descomponga sin luz, para que pueda desaparecer aunque esté cubierto o enterrado. Después de estos pasos, el plástico podría usarse en la vida diaria.

**Frase clave** – Un nuevo tipo de plástico puede diseñarse para descomponerse de forma segura después de su uso, ofreciendo una manera más inteligente de reducir la contaminación por plástico.

The cow of the future? France introduces smaller, low-emission livestock

How can we reduce greenhouse gas emissions? In the wake of the COP30 climate conference in Brazil, attention is turning to cattle. A single cow produces between 154 to 264 pounds of methane gas per year. So could genetics lessen their impact? FRANCE 24's Charlotte Lam reports on what's being called the "cow of tomorrow".
articles.reasoning: The article discusses a significant environmental innovation—developing smaller, low-emission cattle to reduce methane emissions, a major contributor to climate change. This has broad implications for greenhouse gas reduction and climate action globally, providing a tangible, science-based solution with measurable benefits.
articles.personality_title: France develops smaller cows that produce less methane to fight climate change
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Cows produce a lot of methane, a gas that contributes to climate change. After the COP30 climate meeting in Brazil, scientists and farmers are looking for ways to reduce these emissions.

**What happened** – In France, researchers have introduced a new kind of cow that is smaller and releases less methane gas. These cows are called the "cow of tomorrow" because they are designed using genetics to create livestock with a smaller environmental footprint.

**Impact** – This is important because one regular cow can produce between 154 to 264 pounds of methane every year. By having smaller cows that produce less methane, farmers can help reduce greenhouse gases that harm the planet. This idea is a new way to make farming more eco-friendly without stopping people from raising animals.

**What's next step** – Scientists and farmers will continue to test these smaller cows to see how well they work on farms. If successful, more farmers might start using this type of cow to help fight climate change while still producing milk and meat.

**One-sentence takeaway** – France’s new smaller, low-methane cows offer a practical way to reduce farming’s impact on climate change.
articles.personality_title_fr: La France crée des vaches plus petites qui émettent moins de méthane pour lutter contre le changement climatique
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les vaches produisent beaucoup de méthane, un gaz qui contribue au changement climatique. Après la conférence COP30 au Brésil, les scientifiques et les agriculteurs cherchent des solutions pour réduire ces émissions.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – En France, des chercheurs ont présenté un nouveau type de vache plus petite qui émet moins de méthane. Ces vaches, appelées "vaches de demain", sont créées grâce à la génétique pour avoir un impact environnemental réduit.

**Impact** – C’est important car une vache normale peut produire entre 70 et 120 kilos de méthane chaque année. Avec ces vaches plus petites, les agriculteurs peuvent diminuer les gaz à effet de serre qui abîment la planète. C’est une nouvelle façon de rendre l’élevage plus respectueux de l’environnement sans l’arrêter.

**Prochaine étape** – Les scientifiques et les agriculteurs vont continuer à tester ces vaches pour voir si elles sont adaptées aux fermes. Si ça marche, plus d’agriculteurs pourraient utiliser ce type de vache pour aider à lutter contre le changement climatique tout en produisant lait et viande.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Les nouvelles vaches françaises, plus petites et moins émettrices de méthane, offrent une solution concrète pour réduire l’impact de l’élevage sur le climat.
articles.personality_title_es: Francia desarrolla vacas más pequeñas que producen menos metano para combatir el cambio climático
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Las vacas producen mucho metano, un gas que contribuye al cambio climático. Después de la conferencia COP30 en Brasil, científicos y agricultores buscan formas de reducir estas emisiones.

**Qué pasó** – En Francia, investigadores han presentado un nuevo tipo de vaca más pequeña que libera menos metano. Estas vacas, llamadas "vacas del mañana", se crean usando genética para tener un impacto ambiental menor.

**Impacto** – Esto es importante porque una vaca normal puede producir entre 70 y 120 kilos de metano cada año. Con vacas más pequeñas que producen menos metano, los agricultores pueden ayudar a reducir los gases que dañan el planeta. Es una forma nueva de hacer la ganadería más ecológica sin dejar de criar animales.

**Próximo paso** – Los científicos y agricultores seguirán probando estas vacas para ver cómo funcionan en las granjas. Si tienen éxito, más agricultores podrían usar este tipo de vaca para ayudar a combatir el cambio climático mientras producen leche y carne.

**Resumen en una frase** – Las nuevas vacas francesas, más pequeñas y con menos emisión de metano, ofrecen una manera práctica de reducir el impacto de la ganadería en el cambio climático.
